prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Practical Advice for Protecting Confidential Business Information

para.paratext: It is clear that information already in the public domain, published information, information already known to the recipient at the outset of the relevant relationship, information disclosed by the owner to a third party, and professional knowledge gained prior to the formation of the relationship will not normally receive protection from the courts.[1] Accordingly, care should be taken to ensure that current business activities do not result in problems down the road. Information used in connection with certain activities should be reviewed from time to time to avoid unintentional disclosure. This would include information:
published in academic, trade or industry journals;
included in marketing and promotional materials;
provided to the government, professional associations or industry organizations;
included in research results or surveys;
given in connection with joint ventures, partnerships or the sale of a business;
disclosed to financial institutions or insurers;
provided to agents, customers, consultants, distributors or suppliers;
at issue in the course of litigation;
contained on websites or other technology sources.

These are just some examples of the kinds of situations which must be reviewed. Unfortunately, these situations involve common, everyday activities. As a result, they are often taken for granted and ignored as possible sources of unintentional disclosure. The risk is even greater when foreign parties and jurisdictions are involved,[2] as legal principles, business standards, enforcement mechanisms, etc. can vary considerably.

Robin-Nodwell Mfg. Ltd. v. Foremost Developments Ltd. (1966), 52 C.P.R. 244, 38 Fox Pat. C. 43 (Alta. S.C.); O. Mustad & Son v. S. Allcock & Co., [1963] 3 All E.R. 416 (H.L.); Delrina Corp. v. Triolet Systems Inc. (1993), 9 B.L.R. (2d) 140, 47 C.P.R. (3d) 1 (Ont. Ct. (Gen. Div.)), affd 156 O.A.C. 166, 58 O.R. (3d) 339 (C.A.), leave to appeal to S.C.C. refused 21 C.P.R. (4th) vi.
As to the seriousness of this threat, see the book by J. Fialka entitled War by Other Means: Economic Espionage in America (New York: W.W. Norton, 1997).
